sections.name: Imprecasia
Targeting Items
sections.text: An imprecasia can cast *remove curse* on a cursed item rather than on a creature, but they can't use Devour Curse on it. They can only do so on an item that's of a level equal to or less than their own level; on a success, the item is uncursed for 24 hours if it's of a level equal to or higher than the imprecasia's level –4, or uncursed permanently if it's lower level than that.

sources.name: Pathfinder #199: To Bloom Below the Web

link.name: Pathfinder #199: To Bloom Below the Web pg. 83
link.alt: Pathfinder #199: To Bloom Below the Web pg. 83

sections.text:
An imprecasia, commonly known as a curse eater, is a solitary fey drawn to the energy emanating from curses. They appear as emaciated humanoid creatures with shadowy wings, long thin hands with sharp claws, and insectile heads with feathery antenna.  
  
 An imprecasia's appearance in a region signifies the land is troubled, but they're not unpopular creatures. On the contrary, an imprecasia's whereabouts are coveted information, as they have the ability to fully consume curses on objects and creatures. Many carrying the weight of a curse seek out curse eaters, most of whom will gladly accept doomed objects or charitably destroy an individual's curse.  
  
 An imprecasia will never accept the idea of healing a cursed land or blighted region. One might even seek to strengthen the afflictions on a region simply to ensure a regular supply of food. A bolder imprecasia tracks cursed families over generations, feeding off their misfortune until the curse ends or the bloodline dies off. Any who attempt to destroy such curses may find themselves the enemy of an imprecasia defending their source of sustenance.

traits.name: Uncommon
traits.text: Something of uncommon rarity requires special training or comes from a particular culture or part of the world. Some character choices give access to uncommon options, and the GM can choose to allow access for anyone. Less is known about uncommon creatures than common creatures. They typically can't be summoned. The DC of Recall Knowledge checks related to these creature is increased by 2.

traits.name: Fey
traits.text: Creatures of the First World are called the fey

sources.name: Pathfinder #199: To Bloom Below the Web

link.name: Pathfinder #199: To Bloom Below the Web pg. 83
link.alt: Pathfinder #199: To Bloom Below the Web pg. 83

interaction_abilities.name: Scent Curse
interaction_abilities.text: The imprecasia can smell the presence of curses of a level equal to or lower than their own level within 30 feet this is an imprecise sense.

reactive_abilities.name: Drink Death
reactive_abilities.trigger: A creature within 30 feet of the imprecasia is dying
reactive_abilities.effect: The imprecasia inhales, drawing a thin blue streak of vapor out of the dying creature's body into their mouth. The dying creature's dying condition is reduced by 1, and the imprecasia regains 2d10+9 Hit Points.

traits.name: Necromancy
traits.text: Effects and magic items with this trait are associated with the necromancy school of magic, typically involving forces of life and death.

traits.name: Primal
traits.text:
This magic comes from the primal tradition, connecting to the natural world and instinct. Anything with this trait is magical.  
  
A creature with this trait is primarily constituted of or has a strong connection to primal magic.

traits.name: Agile
traits.text: The multiple attack penalty you take with this weapon on the second attack on your turn is –4 instead of –5, and –8 instead of –10 on the third and subsequent attacks in the turn.

traits.name: Finesse
traits.text: You can use your Dexterity modifier instead of your Strength modifier on attack rolls using this melee weapon. You still calculate damage using Strength.

traits.name: Magical
traits.text: Something with the magical trait is imbued with magical energies not tied to a specific tradition of magic. Some items or effects are closely tied to a particular tradition of magic. In these cases, the item has the arcane, divine, occult, or primal trait instead of the magical trait. Any of these traits indicate that the item is magical.

ability.name: Devour Curse

traits.name: Abjuration
traits.text: Effects and magic items with this trait are associated with the abjuration school of magic, typically involving protection or wards.

traits.name: Primal
traits.text:
This magic comes from the primal tradition, connecting to the natural world and instinct. Anything with this trait is magical.  
  
A creature with this trait is primarily constituted of or has a strong connection to primal magic.

ability.text: The imprecasia casts remove curse against a curse afflicting a creature, but with a cast of two actions rather than 10 minutes. If they succeed in removing the curse, they also drains vitality from the creature, causing it to become drained 1 unless it succeeds at a DC 30 Fortitude save (drained 2 on a critical failure). If the curse is removed, the imprecasia doesn't expend that use of *remove curse* as a primal innate spell.

ability.name: Homeland's Hostility

traits.name: Curse
traits.text: A curse is an effect that places some long-term affliction on a creature. Curses are always magical and are typically the result of a spell or trap. Effects with this trait can be removed only by effects that specifically target curses.

traits.name: Enchantment
traits.text: Effects and magic items with this trait are associated with the enchantment school of magic, typically involving mind control, emotion alteration, and other mental effects.

traits.name: Primal
traits.text:
This magic comes from the primal tradition, connecting to the natural world and instinct. Anything with this trait is magical.  
  
A creature with this trait is primarily constituted of or has a strong connection to primal magic.

ability.text: A creature that takes damage from the imprecasia's claws must attempt a DC 30 Will save. On a failure, it treats all terrain within 60 feet of an imprecasia as difficult terrain.
